div.p:
The prints of the essai on the plants of the New Hebrides,
B73.13.01, which M intended to extend the 'solid foundation' of the 'important works of the venerable Dr Asa Gray and of the lamented Dr Berthold Seeman' on 'plants of the Polynesian groups', to include the plants of additional islands and the 'many inland recesses, to which heathen barbarism formerly gave no access' (pp. 3-4). See also M to A. Gray, 7 November 1873. dear Prof. Gray, came by a few hours too late into my hands for being forwarded by last months mail. So I send now a copy of them. I fear that I was unable to consult all your important memoirs on the S. Sea Islands plants, as I cannot within my means obtain all periodicals and works on your plants, and thus readily some essays may escape my notice. Would you do me the great Kindness of glancing over the essay, and should you find that I missed to consult any of your contributions to the volumes of the Academy, or any other of your valuable publications bearing on S. Sea Island plants, — would you then afford me your aid in directing my attention to the here wanting part of the literature of the S. Sea Islands. Perhaps even you would extend your generous goodness so far as to send the portions of your writing, which I ought to have referred to, as I intend to follow up this essay soon by an other on the plants of Samoa.
M published his first paper on Samoan plants as B76.13.02. There were two others, B81.08.02 and B81.10.04, and other descriptions of Samoan plants are scattered through various publications.
Always your regardful & with best newyears salutation

div.p:
Pray convey to Agassiz's son my expression of condolence at the lamented death of his celebrated parent.
Alexander Agassiz; Louis Agassiz died on 14 December 1873. This is a great loss to natural science.
